Although there are advantages in organization to putting all the test
metho=
ds for one system class in one test class, this is where it
becomes a deep =
disadvantage.  I would encourage you to create as many
test classes as you =
need, each with its own setUp method.

   David Saff

On Wed, Jul 1, 2009 a=
t 6:08 PM, mnferrari2000<puneet.lakhina@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I have =
a pretty fundamental question. I have a class under test and to test each o=
f the methods of the class there are different test methods in my test clas=
s. Now testing all these methods requires different test data. Here is wher=
e my question lies, is it possible to annotate the test method to somehow s=
ay use these setup methods, or use this setup method.
>
> I can obviously i=
nclude the data population code within my test method. But in my situation =
there can be two test methods that require the same setup and this would th=
en mean code duplication.
>
> Right now the only way I can think of is to c=
reate these setup methods and call them individually from all my test metho=
ds which require that setup. Is that the right way to go about this?
>
> Th=
anks
